channel.title: NYT > Arts
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Game of Thrones: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 8, Episode 2 Recap: The Things We Do for Love
item.media:description: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau in “Game of Thrones.”
item.description: All over Winterfell, people gathered for a final bit of human tenderness before next week’s big White Walker clash.
item.dc:creator: JEREMY EGNER

item.title: Displaced Artists Open a New Front at the Brooklyn Army Terminal
item.media:description: The skylight-enclosed atrium at the Brooklyn Army Terminal, where 100 artists have rented studio space.
item.media:credit: Celeste Sloman for The New York Times
item.description: For those muscled out of studios across the city, ArtBuilt offers long leases, below-market rents and the mayor’s welcome.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: Taylor Mac’s ‘Gary’ Finds Hope and Humor on a Pile of Corpses
item.media:description: Nathan Lane as the title character in Taylor Mac’s new play, “Gary: A Sequel to Titus Andronicus,” on Broadway.
item.description: This comedic sequel to “Titus Andronicus” finds Nathan Lane and Kristine Nielsen cleaning up after a Shakespearean blood bath.
item.dc:creator: JESSE GREEN
item.category: Gary: A Sequel to Titus Andronicus (Play)

item.title: Live Review: At Coachella, the Gospel According to Kanye West
item.media:description: Kanye West performed atop a miniature mountain made specifically for his set at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival on Easter Sunday.
item.media:credit: Rozette Rago for The New York Times
item.description: After a few of his most difficult years and a brief retreat from the spotlight, the rapper returned with Sunday Service — a performance of spiritual music where he rarely took center stage.
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA
item.category: Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival

item.title: On YouTube, ‘Game of Thrones’ Superfans Prepare for the End
item.media:description: Lena Headey as Cersei Lannister in “Game of Thrones.”
item.description: The HBO fantasy epic has inspired a universe of video commentators and dissectors online. Like other fans, they’re girding themselves for the end of their obsession.
item.dc:creator: DANIELLE DOWLING

item.title: ‘Game of Thrones’: Florence and the Machine’s Frontwoman on That Haunting Closing Song
item.media:description: Florence Welch of Florence + the Machine during a performance in 2018.
item.description: Florence Welch spoke about her feelings toward the song, and about the time she turned down a similar chance back before she was a “Thrones” fan.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER VINEYARD

item.title: Prince’s Unfinished Memoir Will Be Released After All
item.media:description: Prince, in 2015. He had announced a memoir project weeks before he died. Now, it will include the original handwritten treatment for “Purple Rain,” the 1984 film and album.
item.description: The publisher Random House announced on Monday that the “newly envisioned” book would now include rare photographs and handwritten lyrics.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: Michael Jackson Biographers Face History, and the Mirror
item.media:description: “Leaving Neverland” has several Michael Jackson biographers revising their books.
item.description: After child molestation accusations of “Leaving Neverland,” books about the pop icon are already being rewritten. Who will have the last word?
item.dc:creator: REGGIE UGWU

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: ‘Gentleman Jack’ Finds a Swaggering Woman in Want of a Wife
item.media:description: Suranne Jones in an episode of “Gentleman Jack.”
item.description: Suranne Jones is a force of nature in a rollicking HBO period piece, created by Sally Wainwright.
item.dc:creator: JAMES PONIEWOZIK

item.title: ‘Game of Thrones’: Who Is the Mad King, and Why Did Jaime Kill Him?
item.media:description: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau as Jaime Lannister, widely known (and reviled) as the Kingslayer, in a scene from “Game of Thrones.”
item.description: There’s more to the story than Jaime’s one murderous act. Call it a cautionary tale for any quick-to-burn Targaryen with a Lannister for a hand.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER VINEYARD

item.title: ‘Game of Thrones’: Jaime and Brienne ... Free to Love at Last?
item.media:description: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and Gwendoline Christie in “Game of Thrones.” “If they had met in happier times, he wouldn’t have spoken to her,” Christie said about their characters, Jaime and Brienne.
item.description: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and Gwendoline Christie talked about what their characters’ relationship might have been like had they met under different circumstances.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER VINEYARD

item.title: Kanye West Performs New Song During ‘Sunday Service’ at Coachella
item.description: Kanye West was joined by dozens of others in his performance of a new song, “Water,” on Easter Sunday at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.
item.category: Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival

item.title: Tiny Neighborhoods Sprout at the National Building Museum
item.description: A collector, David Weingarten, is donating 3,069 shrunken landmarks to the museum.
item.dc:creator: EVE M. KAHN

item.title: Nonfiction: Two Early Presidents Who Questioned the Wisdom of ‘the People’
item.description: In “The Problem of Democracy,” Nancy Isenberg and Andrew Burstein show that John and John Quincy Adams were skeptical of popular democracy.
item.dc:creator: VIRGINIA DeJOHN ANDERSON

item.title: Nonfiction: Pico Iyer Reflects on a Quarter-Century of Life in Japan
item.description: In “Autumn Light: Season of Fire and Farewells,” the noted journalist finds wisdom in the rituals and routines he shares with his Japanese wife.
item.dc:creator: PHILLIP LOPATE
item.category: Autumn Light: Season of Fire and Farewells (Book)

item.title: BTS Lands a Third No. 1 on the Album Chart in Less Than a Year
item.media:description: The K-pop boy band BTS reached No. 1 again, matching a feat achieved by the Beatles.
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.description: The K-pop boy band reached the top of the Billboard 200 again with “Map of the Soul: Persona,” selling 196,000 full albums in addition to its 37 million streams.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO

item.title: Books of The Times: In Ian McEwan’s Latest, a Ménage à Trois — Software Included
item.description: “Machines Like Me” imagines the relationship between a man, woman and lifelike robot in an alternative 1980s England.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER

item.title: Chasing Rembrandt’s Tulips on Two Wheels
item.media:description: The Keukenhof garden's annual exhibit of bulbs drew almost 1.5 million visitors last year.
item.media:credit: Andy Haslam for The New York Times
item.description: On a bike you can immerse yourself in the sights and smells of a world of blooms in the gardens and fields near the Dutch city of Leiden.
item.dc:creator: SUSANNE MASTERS

item.title: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Gentleman Jack’ and ‘Charm City’
item.description: A new series tells the true story of a woman who defied norms in 19th-century England. And a documentary about Baltimore airs on PBS.
item.dc:creator: SARA ARIDI

item.title: Billions: ‘Billions’ Season 4, Episode 6: Beat or Be Beaten
item.media:description: Paul Giamatti in a scene from “Billions.”
item.description: On this show it often pays to be paranoid. The trouble is knowing which thing to be most paranoid about.
item.dc:creator: SEAN T. COLLINS

item.title: ‘Curse of La Llorona’ Is No. 1 as Box Office Braces for More ‘Avengers’
item.media:description: Roman Christou and Linda Cardellini in “The Curse of La Llorona,” which earned $26.5 million this weekend and beat analysts’ expectations.
item.description: Fox’s faith-based “Breakthrough,” with Chrissy Metz as a mother who prays for her son’s seemingly impossible medical recovery, came in third.
item.dc:creator: GABE COHN

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: In ‘The Appointment,’ the Fetus Sings Out
item.media:description: From left, Jaime Maseda, Scott R. Sheppard, Katie Gould and Brenson Thomas as singing fetuses in the new musical “The Appointment.”
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.description: This uncanny, phantasmagorical work from the Lightning Rod Special troupe is a musical cabaret about abortion. That’s right.
item.dc:creator: BEN BRANTLEY

item.title: 5 Things About Your Book: An Undocumented Woman Struggles to Root Her Family in New York City
item.description: Melissa Rivero’s debut novel, “The Affairs of the Falcóns,” features a family that, like hers did, emigrates to New York from Peru.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS
item.category: The Affairs of the Falcons: A Novel (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: That Man From Stratford
item.media:description: The actor David Garrick, against a bust of Shakespeare.
item.description: “What Blest Genius?,” by Andrew McConnell Stott, and “Shakespeare’s Library,” by Stuart Kells, explore different facets of the history and mysteries of the playwright’s reputation.
item.dc:creator: DOMINIC DROMGOOLE
item.category: What Blest Genius?: The Jubilee That Made Shakespeare (Book)
Shakespeare's Library: Unlocking the Greatest Mystery in Literature (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: A Former Marine Looks Back on Her Life in a Male-Dominated Military
item.media:description: Anuradha Bhagwati, 2011.
item.description: Anuradha Bhagwati’s forceful memoir, “Unbecoming,” tackles sexual harassment, discrimination and the possibilities for redress for American servicewomen.
item.dc:creator: V.V. GANESHANANTHAN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Week in Books
item.media:description: Robert A. Caro at his electric typewriter in 2001; Abby Wambach; an illustration by Mikel Jaso.
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times; illustration by Jillian Tamaki; illustration by Mikel Jaso
item.description: Robert Caro, Abby Wambach, the Mueller report and more.

item.title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Motown 60’ and ‘Book Club’
item.media:description: Smokey Robinson, left, and Cedric the Entertainer host “Motown 60.”
item.description: CBS airs a concert celebrating Motown Records. And catch “Book Club,” with Jane Fonda, Candice Bergen, Diane Keaton and Mary Steenburgen, on Hulu.
item.dc:creator: GABE COHN

item.title: Jayne Wrightsman, Arts Benefactor and Doyenne of High Society, Dies at 99
item.media:description: Jayne Wrightsman, wearing a satin gown by Givenchy, on a Louis XV cut-velvet sofa in 1966. She died on Saturday at the age of 99.
item.media:credit: Cecil Beaton/Condé Nast, via Getty Images
item.description: Mrs. Wrightsman, who had no formal training, became a connoisseur of 18th-century French art and a significant donor to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: Books of The Times: The Mueller Report: A Thorny, Patriotic Addition to a Curious American Bookshelf
item.media:description: Redacted pages from the Mueller report.
item.description: Much of what’s in the report was already known, but our book critic says it still has “the power to shock and appall.”
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: That Decisive Moment: Our Favorite Piano: The Week in Classical Music
item.media:description: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida at Carnegie Hall in 2016. Ms. Uchida announced she would be postponing her April 30 Carnegie recital because of exhaustion; she is still scheduled to play at the hall on May 4.
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.description: Efforts to convince friends to love the piano and George Crumb were among the highlights.
item.category: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center

item.title: Nonfiction: ‘When Brooklyn Was Queer’ Evokes the Borough’s Hidden History
item.description: Hugh Ryan’s new account delves into colorful characters who frequented the area around the Brooklyn Navy Yard — a flourishing center of 19th-century queer life.
item.dc:creator: CALEB CRAIN

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.description: The soul of France. Disappearing glaciers. The most chaotic place on the internet. Bauhaus at 100. And more.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN

item.title: Nonfiction: A Young Poet, a Mysterious Stranger and an El Salvador on the Brink of War
item.description: Carolyn Forché’s “What You Have Heard Is True” recalls her 1970s journey in the company of a revolutionary who wants her to bear witness to his country’s terror and bloodshed.
item.dc:creator: FRANCISCO GOLDMAN
item.category: What You Have Heard Is True: A Memoir of Witness and Resistance (Book)

item.title: carry on: What Andrew Bolton Can’t Travel Without
item.description: The curator oversees the fashion exhibits that influence the annual Met Gala. He often travels internationally for research, and always carries a Moleskine notebook to jot down ideas.
item.dc:creator: NELL McSHANE WULFHART

item.title: The Week in Arts: ‘Gentleman Jack,’ Bad Bunny and a Musical About Psychoanalysis
item.media:description: From left, Tiler Peck and Tyler Angle in “Herman Schmerman.”
item.description: “Lady in the Dark,” a Weill-Gershwin-Hart theatrical collaboration from 1941, is revived at City Center by MasterVoices.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Nonfiction: Why Did We Fight the Iraq War?
item.media:description: President George W. Bush with Condoleezza Rice, Dick Cheney, Donald Rumsfeld and Gen. Richard Myers in 2003.
item.description: Michael J. Mazarr’s “Leap of Faith” argues that the tragedy was the result of a missionary impulse and wishful thinking.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW J. BACEVICH
item.category: Leap of Faith: Hubris, Negligence, and America's Greatest Foreign Policy Tragedy (Book)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Warren Adler, ‘The War of the Roses’ Author, Is Dead at 91
item.media:description: Warren Adler in 1991. He found a niche writing about dysfunctional relationships, like that of Jonathan and Barbara Rose, the couple immersed in a domestic free-for-all in “The War of the Roses” (1981).
item.description: A late-blooming novelist, he had his greatest success with a comedy about a couple in a domestic free-for-all. It became a hit movie.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

item.title: Podcast Review: Michael Lewis Enters the Podcasting Game With ‘Against the Rules’
item.description: Lewis’s seven-part series examines our relationship to authority and to regulation — our mistrust of them and, in some cases, our full-throated hostility toward them.
item.dc:creator: JOHN WILLIAMS

item.title: What They Left Behind: Legacies of the Recently Departed
item.media:description: Mr. Westcott was the only person authorized to carry a camera at the Oak Ridge facilities.
item.media:credit: United States Department of Energy, Oak Ridge
item.description: Some gems from the life’s work of people remembered in obituaries in The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL J. WAKIN
item.category: The Mary Tyler Moore Show (TV Program)

item.title: City Ballet Ordered to Reinstate Male Dancers Fired Over Inappropriate Texts
item.media:description: Amar Ramasar with Sara Mearns in the premiere of Justin Peck’s “Rodeo” in 2015. Mr. Ramasar will return to the company as a principal after receiving mandatory counseling.
item.description: An arbitrator ruled that City Ballet overstepped by firing Zachary Catazaro and Amar Ramasar. Mr. Ramasar will return; Mr. Catazaro has decided not to.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL COOPER

item.title: Popcast: Is Billie Eilish the Future of Pop?
item.description: The 17-year-old musician has been revising the rules of young stardom. But she may be more of a classicist than her aesthetic would suggest.
item.category: When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go? (Album)

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: You’ll Never Dance Alone (a Solo)
item.media:description: Mariana Valencia in her solo “Bouquet” at the Chocolate Factory.
item.description: Mariana Valencia’s autobiographical solo reminds us we are products of our communities and histories, songs we’ve heard and dances we’ve learned.
item.dc:creator: SIOBHAN BURKE

item.title: Critic’s Pick: Review: ‘Bosch’ Is Back, Still on the Straight and Narrow
item.media:description: Titus Welliver, left, and Jamie Hector in “Bosch.”
item.description: The Amazon series based on Michael Connelly’s Los Angeles detective novels returns for a fifth season of unadorned police work.
item.dc:creator: MIKE HALE

item.title: The Playlist: Madonna Dreams Up Her Next Era, and 11 More New Songs
item.media:description: Madonna teams with the Colombian star Maluma on the first song from her 14th album, titled “Madame X.”
item.description: Hear tracks by Mavis Staples, Sheryl Crow and Johnny Cash, Wynton Marsalis and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA, CARYN GANZ and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: Review: A Composer’s Redacted Music and Raucous Noise
item.media:description: Third Coast Percussion performing as part of a Composer Portrait concert devoted to David T. Little’s music on Thursday at Miller Theater.
item.description: Two of David T. Little’s politically charged instrumental works were the halves of a Composer Portrait concert at Miller Theater on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY WOOLFE

item.title: Juice WRLD, the Young Rapper, Confronts Death at a Brooklyn Cemetery
item.media:description: Juice WRLD, a chart-topping rapper from Chicago, visited the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn with Ty Fairconeture, right.
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Catacombs, famous headstones and a place to deposit secrets. “What is this?” he said. “The gates of Hell?”
item.dc:creator: BEN DETRICK

item.title: Fiction: A Suspicious Death Exposes Painful Fissures in a Mojave Desert Town
item.description: In “The Other Americans,” a powerful new novel by Laila Lalami, a diverse group of citizens are forced to question their beliefs and allegiances after a Moroccan immigrant is killed.
item.dc:creator: MADELEINE THIEN

item.title: Amy Schumer, Ali Wong and the Rise of Pregnant Stand-Up
item.media:description: Ali Wong, Christina P., Amy Schumer and Natasha Leggero are among the comedians who have worked their pregnancies into their acts.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times: Photographs via Netflix
item.description: Doing stand-up while pregnant used to be frowned upon. Today you can spot babies on the way on comedy club stages, late-night shows and television specials.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

item.title: ‘Kalank’ Review: A Bollywood Love Story in the Shadow of Partition
item.media:description: Alia Bhatt and Varun Dhawan in “Kalank.”
item.description: Abhishek Varman’s maximalist melodrama delivers spectacle (some of it mind-numbing) but fails to tell a gripping story.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL SALTZ

item.title: Pole Dancing Without Nudity or G-Strings. Just Express Yourself.
item.media:description: Sara Joel, from Long Island, performing at the U.S. Pole Dance Championship at Symphony Space.
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.description: The curious hybrid of art, sport, exotic dance and fitness craze has developed a mainstream following but “it’s still a little naughty.”
item.dc:creator: SIOBHAN BURKE

item.title: ‘When They See Us’ Trailer: Ava DuVernay’s Central Park Five Mini-Series Features Felicity Huffman
item.media:description: Caleel Harris, left, and Michael Kenneth Williams in the trailer for “When They See Us.”
item.description: The actress who pleaded guilty in the college admissions scandal plays the D.A. The powerful trailer also stars Michael K. Williams and John Leguizamo.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FRETTS

item.title: Inside the List: ‘That’s When I Acknowledged What Had Been Simmering Inside Me for Years: Anger’
item.description: The U.S. soccer legend Abby Wambach wants to help other women overcome institutionalized discrimination — and she’s written a book, “Wolfpack,” about it.
item.dc:creator: TINA JORDAN
item.category: Wolfpack: How to Come Together, Unleash Our Power, and Change the Game (Book)

item.title: Children’s Books: Books That Expand the Possibilities of Boyhood
item.description: What does it mean to be a boy now? New nonfiction books show the varied thoughts and experiences of boys facing peril — or just figuring out how to be themselves.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MCMURTRIE
item.category: Crossing on Time: Steam Engines, Fast Ships, and a Journey to the New World (Book)
Rising Water: The Story of the Thai Cave Rescue (Book)
The Good Son: A Story from the First World War, Told in Miniature (Book)
The Heart of a Boy: Celebrating the Strength and Spirit of Boyhood (Book)

item.title: New in Paperback: ‘Warlight,’ ‘Air Traffic’
item.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB

item.title: A Teenage Pierre Boulez, Heard for the First Time
item.media:description: Pierre Boulez in the 1950s. His 1944 work “Prélude, Toccata et Scherzo” has been performed publicly for the first time.
item.description: Listen to excerpts from the piano solo “Prélude, Toccata et Scherzo,” written in 1944, when the modernist master was just 19.
item.dc:creator: SETH COLTER WALLS

item.title: The Week’s Most Interesting Trailers: ‘Dark Phoenix’ and ‘Hobbs & Shaw’
item.description: A blond Jessica Chastain and extensive action scenes liven up those clips, and we finally get to hear Mark Hamill as Chucky in the promo for “Child’s Play.”
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FRETTS

item.title: A Word With: John Cho on Heritage, Hashtags and Hollywood’s Surprises
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.description: He talks about taking the lead — this spring, in a documentary and “The Twilight Zone” — and whether “Harold & Kumar” has smoked its last joint.
item.dc:creator: KATHRYN SHATTUCK
item.category: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (Movie)

item.title: Anatomy of a Scene: How ‘The Curse of La Llorona’ Creates Chills
item.description: The director Michael Chaves narrates a scene from this thriller about a menacing mother.
item.dc:creator: MEKADO MURPHY

item.title: ‘The Curse of La Llorona’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: Michael Chaves narrates a sequence from the thriller.

item.title: For 15 Hours, He’s in Charge of Wagner’s ‘Ring’
item.media:description: The Metropolitan Opera has entrusted the revival of its production of Wagner’s “Ring” to the conductor Philippe Jordan, 44.
item.media:credit: Devin Yalkin for The New York Times
item.description: The conductor Philippe Jordan, 44, is relatively little known in the United States, but he’s at the crossroads of a major career in Europe.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL COOPER
